DOC.HEAD: U.S., Soviet Accounting Venture Launched
DOC.TEXT: American numbers crunchers are the latest capitalists to exploit the budding U.S.-Soviet business romance. Ernst & Young, a leading U.S. accounting and professional services company, said Tuesday it had signed an agreement with Vneshconsult, the Soviet management consulting firm, creating what was described as the first Western-Soviet accounting company, based in Moscow. The American partners will provide training in their worldwide audit methodology for Vneshaudit's Soviet personnel, Ernst & Young said in a news release. ``There is no public accounting profession in the Soviet Union since there has been, until recently, no need for one,'' said James Searing, Ernst & Young's director for international business services. ``Concepts such as the Western understanding of profit measurement and the differences between external and internal auditing and reporting are new for them,'' Searing said. ``Setting up business there requires far more than just adapting one country's accounting standards to another's.'' Ray Groves, co-chief executive of Ernst & Young, said the firm's entry into the Soviet market ``is both a tangible symbol of the new cooperation and a highly practical advance movement for American commerce.'' A number of highly visible American companies have been signing business deals and exploring opportunities in the Soviet Union because of the liberalization encouraged by President Mikhail Gorbachev, who is trying to revitalize his nation's stagnant economy and reduce the state's role. U.S. ventures now range from importing Soviet watches to building the world's largest McDonald's restaurant in Moscow. Ernst & Young, one of the largest accounting firms in the world, was established by the merger of Arthur Young and Ernst & Whinney earlier this year. The company has offices in more than 100 countries.
